titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. This was the first Saturday of leisure from the Capitol, that I have been indulged with for seven weeks; and except a walk to Georgetown about noon, I spent it at home very busily engaged, though in an unprofitable manner— It was in preparation for the debate on my Bill, the fate of which has long been decided— I shall not have time to make half the preparation I should choose; but I shall spend upon it double the time perhaps which I ought.— The winter has been on the whole one of the mildest ever known; but this month comes in with unusual severity.

2. I went this morning to the methodist meeting-house at Georgetown, and heard a preacher whose name I know not. He was not a very good speaker, and the substance of his discourse was very flimsy and superficial.— He was apparently not equal to the person I saw there last Sunday— The remainder of the day and Evening I spent at home very busily engaged.

3. In Senate— The first subject taken up was my Bill respecting foreign Ministers— To which I spoke about an hour and a half. Mr: Smith of Maryland, and Mr: Pickering objected to particular parts of the Bill, but not to its material principle— Mr: Bayard in a speech of some length opposed both the general principle and many of the details.— Mr: Worthington advocated the Bill in its present shape— At length by a vote of 17 to 11 the Bill pass’d to a third reading, with a view then to amend it so as to accommodate it to the opinions of a majority— It is however still most probable that it will not be suffered to pass in any shape— Little other business was done— On Executive affairs, an Indian Treaty was ratified.—and the nomination of Mr: Armstrong was Committed to a select Committee— Mr: Bayard moved a Resolution to ask the President for papers respecting Armstrong’s interference in the case of the ship New-Jersey; which motion was adopted. Adjourned, at half past three— In the afternoon I took a walk with Mrs: Adams and her Sister Kitty— Evening writing. Dr: Mitchill desired me to draw a Bill respecting the Seamen’s fund; and I have also agreed to draw the Report, in the case of the Georgia Land petitions— I had no reason to be satisfied with my performance this day. But reason to thank Heaven that I did not more grossly fail.

4. In Senate— I was beginning to draw up the Report on the Georgia-Land-petitions, but Mr: Greenleaf came to me and said it would be better for them to have nothing done, than such a Bill as I had drawn; without the third section; which I first drew, but which Mr: Bradley insisted upon having expunged— So I desisted, and Bradley is to meet with them this Evening, and see if they can agree upon any thing— The Bill for making Jersey a port of Delivery, and erecting a light-house on Fletcher’s Neck in Maine pass’d—after some discussion— The Bill for punishing the counterfeiting of Coins also pass’d. But words were introduced, as I have all along expected, exactly equivalent to the fourth Section of the Bill, which was struck out as unconstitutional— Mr: Baldwin was the man, who devised this mode of veiling the violation of the Constitution, by the selection of words in which the breach was disguised— It pass’d by yeas and nays 19 to 9. And the Bill itself thus amended 22 to 4. This example proves to me what indeed I have often seen before—that Constitutional difficulties never will stand in the way of a majority— And that even in so select a Body as the Senate of the United States, a mere variation of phrase will contrive a loophole to creep from the most barefaced usurpation of power. Mr: Anderson requested me to publish the Speech I made yesterday, on my Bill, to which I assented. Evening writing at home.

5. In Senate— A Bill authorizing the State of Tennessee to perfect certain Land Titles was partly considered, and then postponed— It is a subject which has consumed much time at every Session since I have been in Congress, but which I do not well understand, and in which I take not much interest— Dr: Logan has brought in a Bill to incorporate a National Academy, which was read a second time and committed to a select Committee of three Members— The Resolution for an appropriation to fortify New-York, and other Ports and Harbours was taken up. Dr: Mitchill after a learned speech proposed to fill the blank for the fortification of New-York with $150,000 which by a silent vote was rejected— Dr: Mitchill was so disconcerted at the decision that he proposed not to take a question on the other parts of the report— Genl: Smith of Maryland however moved to fill the blank with $100,000 which gave rise to some discussion after which the subject was generally postponed. I drew a Bill for the encouragement of the shipping and Navigation of the United States, founded on Genl: Smith’s Resolution, committed to him, Mr: Baldwin and me— Smith himself desired me, or rather as Chairman ordered me to draw the Bill— Evening at home, writing.

6. Committee on the Georgia-land petitions. The Bill I had drawn was submitted to them; and being debated, Mr: Bradley proposed an Amendment which he promised to have in writing for the Committee to-morrow morning.— In Senate, General Smith reported the Bill I drew yesterday at his request— The Bill for the relief of Peter Landais was debated in Committee of the whole at the second reading— Mr: Bradley moved to strike out $6000 and insert 2000 which motion was rejected— On the question of its passage to a third reading, Genl: Sumter moved an adjournment just as the Vice-President was stating the question, which gave him Offence, and he said “Gentlemen should not move an adjournment while he was stating a question[”]— The adjournment however prevailed— We could scarcely keep a quorum this day; Mr: John Randolph having made in the House of Representatives a Speech of three hours against Mr Gregg’s non-importation Resolution, and in the course of which he uttered a very violent philippic against the present Executive, and their course of policy— He has been so exasperated at the attempt to take the management of the House from his hands, and at his defeat on the Secret Bill, that he has poured forth all the ebullitions of his resentment on this question— It is said there is now very warm electioneering in the party, for the next Presidential election, & that Mr: Randolph’s object in his present denunciation is to prevent Mr: Jefferson from consenting to serve again, & Mr: Madison from being his successor— Mr: Randolph’s man is said to be Mr: Monroe— Sed Quere de hoc.

7. In Committee on the Georgia Land petitions, Mr Bradley produced his amendment, which was agreed to; and I undertook to draw up the Bill as amended— The Committee agreed to ask leave to Report by Bill— This was accordingly done— I drew the Bill while the House was in Session, and it was immediately reported— My Bill at the third reading was rejected— The yeas and nays were taken on each of the four Sections— The decision on the first however was on the fate of the whole 17 to 11— Mr: Bayard, Mr: Hillhouse and Mr: Smith of Vermont were its principal opposers— The Bill for the relief of Peter Landais was again taken up, and after further debate pass’d to a third reading: though I have great fears of its final failure.— Mr: Gregg’s Resolutions were again debated in the House; and Mr: Randolph in a second Speech of two hours, renewed his attack on the President and Mr: Madison— I went into the House after the Senate’s adjournment, but he was then just closing his Speech and the House immediately adjourned— I pass’d the whole Evening in reading over Captain Landais’s papers.— Senate adjourn’d to Monday.

8. I was summoned to attend three Committees— On the Rules— On the Philadelphia Memorial; and on the subject of impress’d Seamen— While sitting on the first, the last without me agreed to recommend a postponement of the subject to the next Session.— The Committee on the Rules, Mr: Anderson, Mr: Tracy, and myself attending agreed to some Amendments and additions; and are to meet on Monday to consider the report as completed— We had much conversation with Mr: Anderson, on the late nomination of Mr: Armstrong, which he very much disapproves, but which must be carried. After finishing our business I went into the House which sits to-day; and heard part of the debate on Mr: Gregg’s Resolution— Mr: Williams of S. Carolina was finishing as I went in, and Mr: Bidwell followed him in a speech of about half an hour. It was a tolerably good speech, but indifferently delivered— He has depreciated as an Orator since I heard him in the Senate of Massachusetts— His friends appeared to be pleased with it, but as a popular speaker he never can stand as the rival of John Randolph— Evening at home— Partly below, where I found Mr: Van Cortlandt and Mr: Verplank— The effect of Mr: Randolph’s having thus suddenly turned upon his party is violent, and has thrown them into the greatest consternation— Its ultimate result can as yet scarcely be foreseen.

9. Walk’d to the Capitol this morning with Eliza and Adelaide Johnson. Heard Mr: Glendy, an Irish presbyterian clergyman, now residing at Baltimore— His Sermon was ingenious, well methodized, and brilliant in point of style. His manner good, but his pronunciation strongly marked with the Irish peculiarities— Coming home Mr: Broome, member of the House from Delaware walked with me— Evening at home; reading War in disguise.

10. In Senate— The third of the Resolutions reported by the Committee was taken up— Mr: Smith of Maryland, made a speech of an hour and a half in its favour; after which the question was about to be taken silently and the Resolution would undoubtedly have been rejected— I desired a postponement generally which was agreed to. The Bill containing the Articles of War was taken up at the third reading; and almost gone through; when a motion of Mr: Anderson to introduce a new Article gave rise to some debate and the Senate adjourned— The nomination of Mr: Armstrong was postponed untill to-morrow.

11. The Articles of War were again taken up this day and after much discussion upon Mr: Anderson’s proposition; they were finally agreed to, and the bill pass’d, with all the Amendments reported by the Committee.— Mr: Armstrong’s nomination was considered; and Mr: White made a very able speech against its confirmation— Mr: Smith of Ohio desired a postponement untill to-morrow which was agreed to— The Act consenting to an Act of South Carolina, allowing a tonnage duty at Charleston, on vessels of the United States, was considered in Committee of the whole; and in the midst of the discussion the Senate adjourned.

12. Met the joint Committee, on the Library— Mr: Mitchill, Mr: Baldwin and myself of the Senate— Mr: J. Clay Mr: Dana, and Mr: T. M. Randolph of the house— All present— We pass’d two or three votes and are to meet again— We sat late, and when I went into the Senate I found the S. Carolina tonnage Bill had pass’d to a third reading, while I was absent— The nomination of Mr: Armstrong was advocated by Messrs: Maclay, Moore, and Smith of Vermont, and opposed by Messrs: Wright, Smith of Maryland, Bayard, and Hillhouse— Adjourned.

13. The greatest part of this day was spent in Senate, debating the nomination of Mr: Armstrong, which was supported by Messrs: Worthington, Mitchill, and Bradley, and opposed by Messrs: Wright, Pickering, Tracy, and Smith of Maryland— Mr: Wright moved a postponement, to call for further papers, which was rejected by a small Majority.— Adjourned without taking the question— Mr: Bayard told me he had last Evening some conversation with Mrs: Madison, upon the Presidential electioneering now so warmly carried on—in which she spoke very slightingly of Mr: Monroe.

14. A number of Bills were pass’d at various Stages through the Senate this day— But none which occasioned much debate— The Tennessee land-title Bill pass’d, by yeas and nays. The Senators from North-Carolina, only voted against it— The Brig Heinrich Bill was at Mr: Wright’s request postponed untill next week.— The S. Carolina tonnage Bill was stop’d, by one of the objections which I made against it, to give the members from that State time to introduce a remedial provision for removing it— I am left perfectly alone in the opposition against this Bill, so far as debate is concerned.— It must therefore pass, though of a very pernicious tendency.— The Georgia-land-Bill, pass’d to a third reading without debate, though not without difficulty.— The Bill for the relief of Peter Landais pass’d, with a reduction of the Sum, from 6 to 4000 dollars— In Executive business, the nomination of Mr: Armstrong was again taken up but soon postponed, on the suggestion that dispatches from him had been received by the President, which perhaps might have relation to the subject— A nomination of a Coll: Hammond to a certain military command was also discussed, but no question taken upon it— Adjourned over to Monday— I went into the House of Representatives for a short Time where they were discussing a Resolution introduced by Mr: Nicholson; but heard nothing of much interest— This afternoon Captain Landais called upon me to thank me for the part I have taken in his favour; but to declare that he would not accept the sum of 4000 dollars to which the Senate have reduced the Bill in his favour— I reasoned with him as well as I could to induce a change of his determination, but to no purpose— Genl: Turreau spent the Evening here— He is a very skilful performer on the violin; and accompanied Mrs: Hellen’s Piano-forte, much to our entertainment— Mrs: A. and the other Ladies pass’d the Evening with their Sister Mrs: Boyd— I was of course detained from my occupations.— General Turreau told me that he had been this day in the House of Representatives to hear the debates; but that as Mr: J. Randolph rose to speak, he was afraid of hearing things disagreeable said of his Emperor, and therefore immediately retired.— He thought that a degree of respect for the Chiefs of other Governments ought to be observed by every speaker in a Legislative Assembly— He also told me that the claim of the heirs of Beaumarchais was a just claim; which would be established in any Court of Justice upon Earth— And it was singular that in this Country there was no Court of Justice where its merits could be tried— I note these things for future remembrance

15. I went up to the Office of the Department of State to return Marten’s Summary, which I some time since borrowed there— Saw Captain Landais there, who was making application for a certificate of the proceedings of Congress on his claim with which he intends to demand the interference of France in his favour— The remainder of the day I pass’d, at home, chiefly in writing.— Mr: C. Lee of Alexandria called on me to propose some alteration in the Laws of this District.

16. I went this morning to the Treasury Office, with the expectation of hearing Mr: Laurie, but found there was no preaching there— In the Evening I went with all the young Ladies to the Methodist Meeting in Georgetown, where we heard Mr: Parrott. His Sermon was extemporaneous, and he is apparently quite illiterate— But he had that vehemence of manner which is so attractive to the more ignorant part of the community, and which so greatly multiplies the followers of these sects— Great is the power of a speaker’s earnestness in the cause which he advocates— Mr: R. Peter, and Mr: Johns were there, and came home with us— We found at home Mr: & Mrs: Boyd— Mrs: Adams was very unwell all day, and particularly At Night.

17. The most important business done this day in Senate was the appointment of Mr: Armstrong, which finally prevailed. There was nothing said this day in his favour— The Speakers against him were Mr: Smith of Maryland, Mr: Pickering,
Mr: Wright and myself; who closed the debate. The votes were 15 to 15— And the Vice-President decided in favour of the appointment— Mr: Adair of Kentuckey left his seat to avoid voting— He was averse to the appointment, but had not the courage to vote against it; and by his weakness, this shameful transaction was accomplished. Of the 15 members who voted for this nomination two thirds at least answered with faltering voices— I consider it as one of the most disgraceful acts of Mr: Jefferson’s Administration— A nomination of several new Officers was also this day received— Among others a Surveyor at New-York in the room of Coll: Smith who is removed.— The Vice-President gave notice that he should not make his appearance after this day, during the remainder of the Session.— Mr: & Mrs: Boyd, dined and pass’d the Evening at Mr: Hellen’s— Genl: Turreau also spent the Evening here, and accompanied Mrs: Hellen’s Piano-forte with the violin— My Evening was accordingly diverted from my usual employments.

18. In Senate— General Smith of Maryland was chosen President pro Tempore.— The report of the Committee on the Senate’s Rules was discussed and adopted— Mr: Tracy proposed an additional Rule whereby, the Senate might go into Committee of the whole, and the President might appoint a chairman— This however was strenuously opposed, and after much debate rejected— A Bill for incorporating the presbyterian Congregation at Georgetown pass’d after a powerful struggle, and yeas and nays taken 16 to 10.— The terror of ecclesiastical Corporations is like Falstaff’s terror of the gun-powder Percy, though he be dead.— One of the great difficulties in our Legislation for the district of Columbia, is that every member of Congress brings with him the principles of his own State System, and these are so different that there is scarcely any common doctrine to which appeal in argument can be made.

19. Mr: Jackson, one of the Senators from the State of Georgia died this morning about four O’Clock— His disorder was the dropsy. Immediately on the meeting of the Senate this morning, his Colleague Mr: Baldwin, with tears in his eyes! gave notice of this Event, and express’d his hope that the Senate would take the orders usual on such occasions— Mr: Anderson then moved two Resolutions— One that the Senate would attend the funeral, and that a Committee be appointed to superintend the funeral, and communicate the occurrence to the House of Representatives; and the other that the Senators would wear crape for a month, in honour of the deceased— Both Resolutions pass’d unanimously, and the Senate immediately adjourned— The Committee chosen, are Mr: Anderson, Mr: Sumter and Mr: Wright.— I pass’d the Evening at home, in writing.

20. The badness of the weather obliged me to ride to the Capitol— The Senate barely met—received a Message from the President, respecting some trifling affair on the Spanish frontier— And a Message from the House communicating a Resolution of theirs to attend Mr: Jackson’s funeral, and wear crape for a Month— The funeral procession which was large started soon after 12 O’Clock, and reached the Rock Creek Church about 4— The distance is between 5 and 6 Miles— The Marine Corps attended in a body, and fired three rounds, after the interment, at the grave— I rode with the Speaker, and Mr: Masters and Mr: Russell two members of the House of Representatives— It was five O’Clock before I reached home— Wrote as usual in the Evening.

21. In Senate— The Bill respecting the Brig Heinrich, and the claim against the Danish Government was rejected— My efforts in its favour were vain— The Charleston S.C. Tonnage Bill pass’d— My endeavours against it were fruitless— And in both cases, on the argument I stood alone. The New-York nominations were approved— And the Yazoo Bill was taken up.— Mr: Baldwin made a speech against it; and the Senate adjourned over to Monday— Mr: Anderson came to me and called upon me to support this Bill on the ground of the compact— In the moment of irritation from what had just pass’d I answered him with too much warmth, that I cared nothing for the Bill, and was not obliged to take its defence— It was not my Bill, and its proper fathers must take charge of it— He only replied that he saw I was not in good humour and left me— The Carolina Bill had vexed me, because I consider it as aiming a direct stroke at Massachusetts.— But I am convinced that the most effectual aid I can give to the Georgia-Land Bill, is by remaining silent at least untill the members of the majority have come forward in its favour— In the Evening Mr: Tracy and Mr: Pitken were here.

22. Mrs: Adams was very suddenly taken ill, and with great violence about 1. O’Clock this morning.— We were up with her about two hours after which she was better though much exhausted: she continued very weak this whole day— Except a Walk into Georgetown, I spent the whole day in my chamber, writing

23. Heard Mr: Laurie, at the Treasury, and pass’d the remainder of the day, reading, and writing, in my chamber— First news of the Peace of Presburg between France and Austria— And of Mr: Pitt’s death in England.

24. In Senate— A Letter from Mr: Monroe to the Secretary of State was confidentially communicated by the President to both Houses of Congress, with a request to have it returned, which was done— Much business was dispatched because totally unattended to— An Amendment to the Constitution proposed at the instigation of the State of Pennsylvania, was on the point of passing without a word of discussion, after a formal speech of Mr: Maclay in its favour, for want of a word said against it— I arrested the question barely by asking whether it had been printed— Mr: Bayard then made some observations against it, and the discussion was made the order of the day for next Monday— A Bill to incorporate a National Academy, was as near passing—the question was again stop’d by me; only by enquiring whether a blank was fill’d— It would have pass’d with the blank unfill’d— The question however, and the filling of the blank raised a discussion upon the bill, which was in substance rejected, by an Amendment changing its whole aspect— It was then however Committed— The Yazoo Bill was at my request postponed, Mr: Pickering and Mr: Tracy on both whose votes I rely, being absent— The question would have been taken as in the other cases without a word of discussion, and the bill probably would have failed.— I dined at Mr: Boyd’s; and as in almost every instance when I dine abroad, lost my Evening by it.

25. Mr: Tracy being in Senate this day, we had a bill considered which occasioned some debate— A Bill for repealing the Law by which the public Stocks are receivable in payment for the public Lands— It came from the House of Representatives, and has been long before a Committee of the Senate, who reported several Amendments— It pass’d with all the Amendments to a third reading; against the opposition of Mr: Adair, and Mr: Hillhouse— Evening at home— Letter from Coll: Smith.

26. Met Mr: Anderson, and Mr: Tracy upon two Committees— One upon the Bill relating to foreign Coins; on which the Committee agreed to the report and amendments to the Bill, drawn up by Mr: Tracy— And the other, upon the petition of Gilbert C. Russell, on which the papers were examined, but we had not time to agree on a report. In Senate the principal debate was on the bill yesterday discuss’d, which was again debated at the third reading— Mr: Worthington had yesterday offered a Resolution for stopping all credit upon the sales of the public Lands— This was also much debated this day— Adjourned without coming to a decision.— I yesterday moved for a Committee, on the Laws of this District, for the purpose of introducing Mr: Lee’s projected Bill— The Committee was this day appointed— Mr: Baldwin and Mr: Wright, with myself— Mr: & Mrs: Boyd— Mr: Tracy, Mr: Pitken, and Mr: Stedman pass’d the Evening with us at Mr: Hellen’s.

27. Met the Committee on the District Laws— But Mr: Wright had objections against Mr: Lee’s Bill— I asked him to draw up a Bill to his own taste— And he agreed to draw one up for to-morrow Morning— The day was spent in Senate, debating a Bill to provide defence for the territory of Orleans; by giving away lands to settlers on condition of Militia Service. It finally pass’d to the third reading 13 to 13. by the casting vote of the President— I moved that the Georgia-Land-Bill should be made the order of the day to-morrow, which was agreed to— Evening at home untill 9. when I went to Mr: Boyd’s; where Mrs: Adams had been the afternoon and Evening.

28. The appropriation Bill came from the House of Representatives, and pass’d to the second reading.— I reported a Bill, partly drawn by Mr: Wright, and partly Mr: Lee’s—respecting the fees, and some other judicial affairs in the District. Mr: Tracy’s new Coin Bill was read the second time, and committed to a select Committee— At 12 precisely the Georgia Land Bill was taken up, and I opened the debate with some remarks in support of it— It was then opposed by Messrs: Baldwin, & Maclay,
and supported by Messrs: Bradley, Smith of Vermont, Bayard, Pickering and Wright untill half past three— The discussion was perfectly cool and temperate— Mr: Turner called for the yeas and nays— Just before the question was taken Mr: Sumter moved a postponement untill Monday, which however did not obtain— The Bill pass’d—19 yeas and 11. Nays. Mr: Tracy moved an adjournment untill Monday; but this was denied on Account of the Appropriation Bill— We are to meet to-morrow— At 10 I had met the Committee on G. C. Russell’s petition and we agreed that Mr: Anderson, the chairman should report the a Bill in his favour.— I went with Messrs: Pickering, Tracy and J. C. Smith to Mr: Duvall’s; where we dined, and spent the Evening— We met there Mr: Bayard, and Messrs: Dana, J. Campbell, Goldsborough, and Kelly, of the House of Representatives— Mrs: Adams, and Mrs: Goldsborough dined also there; and a Miss Young— The Company in the Evening was numerous, and we had cards— Late Home.

29. The Senate was thinly attended; and did very little business, except referring to a select Committee the Appropriation Bill— Adjourned between 12. and 1. I went into the lobby of the House of Representatives, where I found them engaged on a Question to reject the Georgia-Land Bill at the first reading— After a warm Speech of Mr: John Randolph, it was rejected 62 to 54.— I spent the remainder of the day at home reading and writing.

30. Heard Mr: Laurie at the Treasury— The Ladies went to the Capitol and heard a Mr: Hargrove of the Swedenborg Church preach a Sermon on the Mosaic Account of the Creation— I spent the day and Evening principally in writing— Called at Mr: Boyd’s for Mrs: Hellen and Mrs: Adams who had been there to tea.

31. Met the Joint Committee on the Library; and we made some further progress in our business— We agreed that the principal part of the fund appropriated for this year should be expended by Dr: Mitchell, Mr: Clay and myself during the recess in collecting Books in Boston, New-York and Philadelphia, as the occasion may offer— We are to meet again— In Senate, the Amendment to the Constitution proposed by Mr: Maclay, was after some discussion postponed to the first Monday in December next. The Bill in favour of Hamet Caramelli was read the third time, and the blank filled— I opened the debate upon it, by calling on the Committee for the reasons on which they reported it— After some remarks from Messrs: Bradley, Wright, and Baldwin, the Senate adjourn’d without decision— Dined at Mr: Boyd’s, with Mr: Hellen, Mrs: Johnson and Caroline— Spent the Evening also there.

Day. Very little variation since the beginning of the year— The only exception is a less frequent attendance upon Committees— That preparatory part of the public business being chiefly accomplished. But the business in the Senate itself has become proportionally more urgent— My attention is not more intermitted.
